title-group.article-title: THE SECRET CHAIN: JUSTICE AND SELF-INTEREST IN MONTESQUIEU'S "PERSIAN LETTERS"

abstract.p: Montesquieu's Persian Letters has long been thought to conceal a secret chain uniting the various letters which comprise the work. An examination of the historical context of the Persian Letters, the characters' remarks on justice and self-interest, and the important literary techniques that Montesquieu employs, helps to bring the secret chain to light. The work's letters are written and sequenced to show how self-interest can overawe justice, emphasizing the need for fair and reasonable third party involvement in order to achieve justice in human affairs. Montesquieu calls upon readers to serve as the final link in this chain, prompting the reader ultimately to consolidate the Persian Letters' treatment of politics, philosophy and morality.

Mark Waddicor notices that this is one of the disadvantages of using letters in the way that Montesquieu does; it gives the work an impression of incoherence. See Mark H. Pauline Kra argues that there are six distinct themes in the Persian Letters, arranged in discrete sequences, and that this is the secret chain. See P. Kra, 'The Invisible Chain of the Lettres persanes', Studies on Voltaire and the Eighteenth Century, XXXIII (1963), pp. 7-60, p. 53. That some letters focus more upon one topic than another is scarcely a secret, however, and it would hardly be worth keeping if it were. Furthermore, some themes, such as that of justice and its relation to self-interest, span the letters without regard for Kra's classification.

As Montesquieu puts it, 'C'est toujours par un retour sur eux-mêmes qu'ils agissent: nul n'est mauvais gratuitement. Il faut qu'il y ait une raison qui détermine, et cette raison est toujours une raison d'intérêt' (Letter 83). Cf. Montesquieu does not use the phrase 'amour-propre' to make his points here, but instead suggests that it is a reason of interest — 'un raison d'intérêt' — that creates problems for observing and actualizing justice (Letters 83, 90). Frederick Keener reckons that the notion of amour-propre is 'the most troublesome element in eighteenth-century psychology'; see Keener, The Chain of Becoming, pp. 55 ff. Cf. Voltaire, Dictionnaire Philosophique, in Les Œuvres Complètes de Voltaire, Vol. XXXV, ed. U. Kôlving (Oxford, 1994 [1764]), pp. 334-6.

Sorel, Montesquieu, p. 7. Carr notices that Usbek and Rica may stand for a distant monarch, perhaps Louis XIV, one 'who in some sense is remote from his obligations and responsibilities'. Given the differences in character between Usbek and Rica, one expects that it may be better simply to see Usbek as a distant authority figure, since he is the remote ruler of his seraglio. See Carr, 'The Secret Chain of the Lettres persanes', pp. 335-6.

Sorel also contends that, in the later letters of the work, Montesquieu 'developed whatever came into his head, just as it occurred to him'. He adduces no hard evidence to support this idea, however; and his suggestion seems to imply that the Persian Letters is unfinished or thrown together, which it is not. See Sorel, Montesquieu, pp. 44-5.

Alan Gilbert appears to contend that Usbek's views alone are decisive to show that Montesquieu did not endorse the 'antityrannical' implications of the Persian Letters', see Alan Gilbert, ' "Internal Restlessness": Individuality and Community in Montesquieu', Political Theory, 22 (1994), pp. 45-70, p. 58.

It is not at all evident that Usbek deceives himself about his seraglio. Early in the work, Usbek shows much suspicion about the women under his rule, some of which may be justified, and so he may not labour under some false conception on that matter (Letters 2, 20).

David Carrithers argues that crimes are 'matters of conscious choice' for Montesquieu, and adduces passages from Letter 83 as evidence. See David W. Carrithers, 'Montesquieu's Philosophy of Punishment', History of Political Thought, XIX ( 1998), pp. 213^10, p. 219. Carrithers acknowledges Montesquieu' s statement that self-interest is always a 'determining cause' of unjust actions; but Montesquieu's position in the Persian Letters seems to be that self-interested actions are not always chosen with a range of options clearly in view. See also Mason, Montesquieu's Idea of Justice, p. 150; Montesquieu, The Spirit of the Laws, Part 1, Bk. 1.

Robert Loy argues that the secret of the Persian Letters is its organization: the book is ordered around a secret question, viz., 'How can anyone be himself?'. See Loy, Montesquieu, pp. 52-3, 55. Loy's thesis fails to connect the less prominent characters to the chain, however, and as such it neglects to consider those characters' contributions. Loy also says little about the ideas of justice and self-interest that Montesquieu expresses in the book, so the purview of his thesis is not sufficiently broad.
Cf. Hundert and Nelles, who suggest: 'The isolation of the self from others... is the foundation of despotism'; Hundert and Nelles, 'Theatrical Space', p. 240 (emphasis added).

Consider Marsilius of Padua on this question: 'no judgment, so far as possible, should be entrusted to the discretion of the judge, but rather it should be determined by law and pronounced in accordance with it'. See Marsilius of Padua, Defensor Pads. Vol. 2 of The Defender of Peace, trans. A. Gewirth (New York, 1956 [1324]), p. 38; see also pp. 37-44, 107-8.

Laufer proposes that the secret chain is the tragic contradiction between philosophical inquiry and human blindness that the Persian Letters illustrates. See Laufer, 'La réussite romanesque', pp. 196, 200. The fragility of moral reason is an important theme in the Persian Letters, as I have argued; but most readers will see that the book has the tragic theme Laufer identifies, so Laufer's thesis does not satisfy the criterion of secrecy. Nor does Laufer properly take account of what the characters say on the topic of justice: instead, he dismisses Montesquieu's careful words as 'nervous and rapid' dissertations. See ibid., p. 202. Cf. Singerman, 'Réflexions sur une métaphore', p. 197.
Carr, 'The Secret Chain of the Lettres persanes', p. 336.

Cf. Loy, Montesquieu, p. 101, who suggests that, at the time Montesquieu wrote the Persian Letters, he accepted the superiority of monarchy, and the liberty defined and measured in terms of sovereign order. Betts takes a much more sensible position, noticing that Montesquieu shows 'admiration for states that have rejected or rebelled against monarchy' in Letters 76, 81 and 86; see Betts, Montesquieu, pp. 75-7. Desserud argues that Montesquieu's interest in moderate forms of government 'extends at least back to the time of his writing of the Persian Letters'', see Desserud, 'Virtue, Commerce and Moderation', p. 607.
See Shackleton, Montesquieu, p. 38.

Montesquieu distinguishes between civil and international law in Letter 94, proposing that the respective principles of justice regulating each field may be very different. This may not mean that justice per se fails to unite principles of civil and international law for Montesquieu, but simply that the two respective realms of principles are not coextensive.

Waddicor suggests that, in Montesquieu's view, whereas a subjective element may always be present in people's perceptions and judgments, nevertheless people can use reason to ascend towards an understanding of justice and morality. See Waddicor, Montesquieu, pp. 39—43 ff.

Montesquieu seems to think that this will rarely be required in international conflicts, however, since the subjects in dispute are almost always clearly defined and easily decided, as he puts it (Letter 95).

Many Natural Law theorists thought that God could not rightly violate or alter principles of justice, but argued instead that there must be independent moral grounds to which even God would have to appeal for justification. Hugo Grotius expressed an early form of the idea in 1625, in the Prolegomena to his De lure Belli ac Pads. Other Natural Law theorists of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, who expounded variations of the doctrine, include Samuel von Pufendorf (De lure Nature et Gentium Librii Octo, 1672), Jean-Jacques Burlamaqui (Principes du droit naturel, 1747), and Emerich de Vattel (Le Droit des Gens, 1758). See A.P. d'Entrèves, Natural Law (London, 1951), ch. 3; cf. Voltaire, 'Remerciement sincère à un homme charitable', in Vol. V of Montesquieu's De l'Esprit des lois (Paris, 1816 [1750]), pp. 257-62. See also John Haldane, 'Religious Toleration', Synthesis Philosophica, 17 (1994), pp. 21-6, pp. 24-5; Meyer, 'Politics and Morals', p. 857; Loy, Montesquieu, p. 89. See also Berlin, 'Montesquieu', pp. 143, 152-3; Montesquieu, The Spirit of the Laws, Part 1, Bk. 1.

Cf. Adam Smith's notion of the 'impartial spectator', as he articulates it in the sixth edition of The Theory of Moral Sentiments. Smith proposes that 'we endeavour to examine our own conduct as we imagine any other fair and impartial spectator would examine it', arguing that the only way people can properly assess their motives and sentiments is if they 'remove [themselves]... from [their] own natural station' (Part III, ch. 1). This distance can be gained only by attempting to look upon our sentiments and motives 'with the eyes of other people, or as other people are likely to view them', as he says. See Smith, The Theory of Moral Sentiments, ed. D.D. Raphael and A.L. Macfie (Oxford, 1976 [6th edn. 1790]), pp. 109-10 ff., 154-6.
See Richter, The Political Theory of Montesquieu, p. 47.

Hermeneutical accounts of the complex interactions between reader and work are instructive here. On the notion of the 'fusion of horizons' between the world of the reader and the world of the work, see Hans-Georg Gadamer, Truth and Method, ed. J. Cumming and G. Barden, trans. W. Glen-Doepel (London, 2nd edn., 1989), pp. 306-7, 396-401. See also Paul Ricoeur, Time and Narrative, Vol. 1, trans. K. McLaughlin and D. Pellauer (London, 1984), pp. 77-8.

Perhaps for this very reason, Montesquieu writes in his Reflections that the nature and design of the Persian Letters is 'so obvious that it can only deceive those who are inclined to deceive themselves'.
